Subject: Re: [neat] Re: On general applicability of HyperNEAT and extending
 the CPPN
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=561746680; y=x-llgXjFRm93bLdJiEnkZ2MKOKTIQu41Bg_JWlouFj2ghEsm0VA

------=_Part_4851543_1707062386.1433321285342
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Very interesting. As I am working on my ES HyperNEAT extension now, maybe I=
 can explore some of these possibilities if I get a chance. What I'm doing =
is fairly ambitious already and I'm only going to be on my "sabbatical" for=
 a month or so. I want to do "everything" but as always time is of the esse=
nce.=C2=A0

Kind Regards,

Fred Mitchell,=C2=A0


+49 (0)15 259 409475, Sky=
pe: flajann
 


     On Monday, 1 June 2015, 9:08, "kstanley@... =
[neat]" <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
   

 =C2=A0   Jonurena, good questio=
ns, here are my thoughts:

1)=C2=A0 The main issue with ES-HyperNEAT is tha=
t it is much newer than NEAT so it is less understood.=C2=A0 In principle i=
t may be true that it can supplant NEAT in various situations because it ca=
n configure its own substrate, but it merits more experimentation to demons=
trate that.=C2=A0 Personally I think ES-HyperNEAT's initial results are qui=
te intriguing and it would be great to see more investigation of what it ca=
n do.=C2=A0 When it is difficult to situate the inputs spatially, one optio=
n is to use the "multi-spatial substrate" setup from http://eplex.cs.ucf.ed=
u/papers/pugh_gecco13_revised.pdf , but that would need to be combined care=
fully of course with ES-HyperNEAT, which I don't think has been attempted y=
et.

2) In general there is nothing to prevent providing a temporal dimensi=
on to the CPPN, but you'd have to think carefully about what a connection b=
etween T1 and T2 actually means, because it seems to imply a sequence of ne=
tworks connected to each other through time, which indeed could be interest=
ing, but you'd need to make sure it's really what you intend.=C2=A0 It's al=
so important to note that adding more input dimensions to ES-HyperNEAT can =
in principle make it a lot more expensive to generate the substrates becaus=
e ES-HyperNEAT searches through the hypercube to find the nodes and connect=
ions, so if the hypercube is higher-dimensional, that search really blows u=
p.=C2=A0 However, there are potential shortcuts such as searching cleverly =
only through cross-sections (which is what the most recent ES-HyperNEAT pap=
er does) to avoid have to search through a massive hypercube, but even then=
 the blowup issue might not be easy to address in this way with a lot of in=
puts dimensions.

3) Regarding signed versus unsigned activation functions,=
 the outputs are the most dangerous part because if you need negative outpu=
ts then you have to be careful that output activation functions are signed.=
=C2=A0 However, with internal nodes it is less clear what is essential give=
n that negative weights on connections can yield similar functionality to n=
egative outputs of activation functions.=C2=A0 As a rule of thumb, I think =
it's safe to try to be consistent, that is, stay with signed or unsigned in=
 general internally, but I'd look at specific HyperNEAT implementations to =
see how they handle this detail as precedent.=C2=A0 This might be an intere=
sting topic for further discussion.=C2=A0 It's a bit esoteric but different=
 people probably have different opinions.=C2=A0 My guess though is that in =
the end it is not crucial and the implications of selecting one set or anot=
her (or some signed and some unsigned) are probably not extreme either way.=
=C2=A0 But of course it could be investigated empirically as well.

Best,

=

    <div id=3D"yiv1342536281ygrp-text">
  =
    
      
      <div>Jonurena, good questions, here are my thoughts:<br c=
lear=3D"none"><br clear=3D"none">1)  The main issue with ES-HyperNEAT =
is that it is much newer than NEAT so it is less understood.  In princ=
iple it may be true that it can supplant NEAT in various situations because=
 it can configure its own substrate, but it merits more experimentation to =
demonstrate that.  Personally I think ES-HyperNEAT's initial results a=
re quite intriguing and it would be great to see more investigation of what=
 it can do.  When it is difficult to situate the inputs spatially, one=
 option is to use the "multi-spatial substrate" setup from <a rel=3D"nofoll=
ow" shape=3D"rect" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers=
/pugh_gecco13_revised.pdf">http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/pugh_gecco13_revi=
sed.pdf</a> , but that would need to be combined carefully of course with E=
S-HyperNEAT, which I don't think has been attempted yet.<br clear=3D"none">=
<br clear=3D"none">2) In general there is nothing to prevent providing a te=
mporal dimension to the CPPN, but you'd have to think carefully about what =
a connection between T1 and T2 actually means, because it seems to imply a =
sequence of networks connected to each other through time, which indeed cou=
ld be interesting, but you'd need to make sure it's really what you intend.=
  It's also important to note that adding more input dimensions to ES-=
HyperNEAT can in principle make it a lot more expensive to generate the sub=
strates because ES-HyperNEAT searches through the hypercube to find the nod=
es and connections, so if the hypercube is higher-dimensional, that search =
really blows up.  However, there are potential shortcuts such as searc=
hing cleverly only through cross-sections (which is what the most recent ES=
-HyperNEAT paper does) to avoid have to search through a massive hypercube,=
 but even then the blowup issue might not be easy to address in this way wi=
th a lot of inputs dimensions.<br clear=3D"none"><br clear=3D"none">3) Rega=
rding signed versus unsigned activation functions, the outputs are the most=
 dangerous part because if you need negative outputs then you have to be ca=
reful that output activation functions are signed.  However, with inte=
rnal nodes it is less clear what is essential given that negative weights o=
n connections can yield similar functionality to negative outputs of activa=
tion functions.  As a rule of thumb, I think it's safe to try to be co=
nsistent, that is, stay with signed or unsigned in general internally, but =
I'd look at specific HyperNEAT implementations to see how they handle this =
detail as precedent.  This might be an interesting topic for further d=
iscussion.  It's a bit esoteric but different people probably have dif=
ferent opinions.  My guess though is that in the end it is not crucial=
 and the implications of selecting one set or another (or some signed and s=
ome unsigned) are probably not extreme either way.  But of course it c=
ould be investigated empirically as well.<br clear=3D"none"><br clear=3D"no=
ne">Best,<br clear=3D"none"><br clear=3D"none">ken</div>

    </div>
